title: crit on custom lettering
content:
Hello, I am new to Typophile. I am going to dive right on in and see if I can get some professional, honest feedback on a custom lettering mark I am working on for a logo.

I want some good feedback on any and all typographic rules, spacing, weight consistancy etc. Just let me have it.

I am at the point right now where I know its not perfect, but would like to receive feedback before I move forward. right now the a, e, and s bother me a bit.

Thanks!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804224827im_/http:/typophile.com/files/franers_5566.jpg)
author: LinkCreative

comments.content: Looks kinds retro, but I would suggest to start looking at similar fonts for ideas on how to make the letters relate to each other more. Also the r connection looks a bit too contrived like something Ford would do. ;-)

Thanks. that is what I did with my revised version.. dunno why it didnt show with my post above. Here it is again.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804224827im_/http:/typophile.com/files/asdfadf_5030.jpg)
See what you are saying about the R.. hmm .. I tried to atleast transition it better. wonder if I should rework the whole R.

A cursive script style r might be worth trying.Have a look at:  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/alphabetsoup/metroscript/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804224827/http:/new.myfonts.com/fonts/alphabetsoup/metroscript/ "http://new.myfonts.com/fonts/alphabetsoup/metroscript/")  
 [http://new.myfonts.com/search/bello+pro/fonts/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140804224827/http:/new.myfonts.com/search/bello+pro/fonts/ "http://new.myfonts.com/search/bello+pro/fonts/")
I like it because it has this whole retro varsity or soda-jerk feel. Could you post a character map?
Its nice I think less weight on the F (more thick and thin) Is this a one-off or are you doing an Alphabet
